comment.author: 72646284@N00
comment._content: A link to the Dillon map: flickr.com/map?place_id=w6Xyj0CbApW9kRZ3

comment.author: 23176588@N02
comment._content: What a beautiful example of Italianate architecture!  Is this building still standing?

comment.author: 36015057@N00
comment._content: If that building isn't still standing, it's a crime.  This kind of architecture should never be replaced by supermarkets and gas stations.  It has such history, such stories to tell.  I hope someone has saved it.

comment.author: 10951005@N03
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Old Commercial Blocks, and we'd love to have your photo added to the group.

comment.author: 87842398@N00
comment._content: Interesting that they advertised that it is air conditioned. Probably a pretty rare thing at that time and a strong enticement to potential customers of the cafe on a hot day.

comment.author: 23563103@N05
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called U.S. 91, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 51035826751@N01
comment._content:
Looking at the TIF, the whole block is bars and rooms for rent. I've no doubt the block was torn down for being a public nuisance. 

The cafe at the corner was open 24 hours.

I went along former US 91 in Dillion with Google Street View and didn't see this building.

comment.author: 51035826751@N01
comment._content: The Budweiser sign is in front of the Moose Bar, next to which is the Moose Shop, next to which is the entrance for the Moose Rooms.

comment.author: 51035826751@N01
comment._content: I stand corrected, the block does appear to still be there: www.flickr.com/photos/11868850@N00/2513123722 The lower facades of the Moose Bar and Lobby Bar (now the Longhorn Saloon) have been redone, but those are the same buildings (note "H. Cushing" in roof pediment). This identified the intersection as Montana and Bannack. Unfortunately, Google Street View reveals that the corner building (with the cafe) has been replaced by an ugly steel thing (the Rusty Duck Casino).

comment.author: 28277802@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Commercial Buildings With Towers, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 19831025@N06
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Historical Sites Of The U.S., and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 56923624@N00
comment._content: I just looked it up on google maps. The building IS still standing, however it appears that everything that's beautiful about it in this photo has been destroyed. Shame... maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&geo...

comment.author: 41874210@N00
comment._content: The 60s were a destructive decade. While buildings were being modified (for the worse) earlier than this it seems it was widespread in the 60s as were new highways which were so much uglier than the old interesting roads. It likely came down to cost of upkeep though I'm sure there were those who thought the modernization was more attractive at the time.
